SP.P: Oh, he takes me for a lawyer. The paroxism is exceedingly strong. Who is there? Order a coach, and let the three keepers convey him to Chelsea.

SP.SPEAKER: Prig.
SP.P: Me to Chelsea? Iet any body touch me that dare!

SP.SPEAKER: Helle.
SP.P: Ay, ay, we will see that.

SP.SPEAKER: Prig.
SP.P: This is some conspiracy, I suppose, to bam, to chouse me out of my money.

SP.SPEAKER: Helle.
SP.P: You will take him to Chelsea.

SP.SPEAKER: Prig.
SP.P: Hands off!

SP.SPEAKER: Helle.
SP.P: And, as you see he is violent, Iet him have the back room, with the barr'd windows, up two pair of stairs.

SP.SPEAKER: Prig.
SP.P: Me to Chelsea? me barr'd windows, and back room two-pair of stairs?

SP.SPEAKER: Helle.
SP.P: If the fit should encrease, put on the streight waistcoat. I shall call myself in the evening.

SP.SPEAKER: Prig.
SP.P:
Let me go, gentlemen! This is a damn'd contrivance, to rob me! Unhand me, or you shall be all swing'd and sous'd! imprison a citi∣zen, that only comes for his money? Damn me,
Jack Wilkes's affair will be but a flea-bite to this!

SP.SPEAKER: Helle.
SP.P: If this is the case, on with the waistcoat.

SP.SPEAKER: Flaw.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha! poor Prig! in what a pi∣teous plight have you left him!—But the Air∣castles will all be here immediately, so take care we are not interrupted.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fl.
SP.P: As they are so exceedingly credu∣lous, the business will soon be dispatched.

SP.SPEAKER: Flaw.
SP.P: In a trice. I have stipulated that your provision shall be secured before the solemniza∣tion.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fl.
SP.P: Right, right; perfectly right.

SP.SPEAKER: Flaw.
SP.P: But have you properly prepared the girl for the purpose?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fl.
SP.P: Her part will be easy.

SP.SPEAKER: Flaw.
SP.P: True; but she should be adroit; as events may arise, that will require some little skill: Who the deuce have you got?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fl.
SP.P: Why, I considered that as a very ticklish point; it would be dangerous to trust, and difficult to find in this town a suitable subject: Don't you think that the black girl I brought with me from Boston—

SP.SPEAKER: Flaw.
SP.P: The negro? zounds, her complexion will betray her at once!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fl.
SP.P: I have thought of an expedient to secure us from that.

SP.SPEAKER: Flaw.
SP.P: It is true, these people have no great penetration; but what we do—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fl.
SP.P: Must quickly be done: I will just speak to the girl. [Calls.] Marianne!

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: What you want, Missy?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fl.
SP.P: Go in and throw yourself on the bed; and, do you hear? let the window be shut, and the curtains drawn exceedingly close.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Yes, Missy.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flee.
SP.P: And whoever speaks to you, don't you chatter and talk, but sigh now and then, as if you were sick: You will be only asked a ques∣tion or two; as, if you are ill? or are better? to which you need say nothing but yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Nothing but iss. I take care, Missy, never you fear.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flee.
SP.P: And, Marianne, no candle!

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: No, no, Missy.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fl.
SP.P: Oh, she will answer our purpose, I warrant: Besides, unless they are very pressing to see her, there will be no occasion to produce her at all.

SP.SPEAKER: Flaw.
SP.P: But, I beg your pardon, there will: by my directions, the son is provided with presents, with a view to propitiate his Venus.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fl.
SP.P: There they are! Mr. Flaw, you will receive them? It will be right for me to retire, to see if all things within are in order.
SP.STAGE: Enter Aircastle, Mrs. Aircastle, and Toby.

SP.SPEAKER: Air.
SP.P: I tell you the boy is an absolute sight, and I should not wonder if the young lady was to—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Air.
SP.P: You wonder? and pray who made you a judge of the proper—

SP.SPEAKER: Flaw.
SP.P: Hush, hush! for Heaven's sake, hush! consider where you are!

SP.SPEAKER: Air.
SP.P: She is at her old tricks, Mr. Flaw; there is no—

SP.SPEAKER: Flaw.
SP.P: A key lower, good Sir, if you please! You will frighten the family.

SP.SPEAKER: Air.
SP.P: By her good will, I should never open my mouth, but to eat.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Air.
SP.P: I know but little else that it's good for.

SP.SPEAKER: Flaw.
SP.P: Nay, madam, now you are as faulty as he. Only think what a strange impression this will make on the ladies within! I beg you will suspend your warfare a while.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Air.
SP.P: Well, well!

SP.SPEAKER: Flaw.
SP.P: And no contradiction, I beg; but be attentive and polite to each other, as people of fashion should be: You may renew hostilities, and make up for lost time, as soon as you are out of the house.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Air.
SP.P: Why, how is it my fault, Mr. Flaw?

SP.SPEAKER: Air.
SP.P: Nor shall it be mine: For man and wife to quarrel before folks is rather rudish, I own; by ourselves, indeed, it is a pretty innocent amusement enough—Tom Testy, of our town, used to say—his wife was a Devonshire girl; if I am not mistaken, from Plymouth—where, by the bye, they have the best John Dories in England—Old Quin, one summer, went thither on purpose—

SP.SPEAKER: Flaw.
SP.P: And if, Mr. Aircastle, you would con∣tract your conversation a little—To be sure, your manner is pleasing, and your matter full of instruction; but as we meet upon business—

SP.SPEAKER: Air.
SP.P: I believe you are right, Mr. Flaw. Come, my love; let us shew him how polite we can be, if we please.—Dear Mrs. Aircastle, how I admire your taste! these here skirts of the boy's are so light and genteel, and so airy—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Air.
SP.P: True; I am happy, my dear, that I have your approbation: Those we got made in the country, trapes and dangle like a parcel of petticoats.

SP.SPEAKER: Air.
SP.P: Right, my love.—For all the world, like a Hounslow post-boy! His whole figure is just like a spider, nothing but legs; a mere couple of stilts!—And then that top to his wig, my dear child—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Air.
SP.P: Gives a fashionable turn to his face; and then adds to the height.

SP.SPEAKER: Air.
SP.P: It has indeed, my soul, a prodigious happy effect.—A block, popping out of a hair∣cutter's window, up two pair of stairs in the Strand.—And then that bunch at his back—

SP.SPEAKER: Flaw.
SP.P: Hush! here comes the lady.
This, madam, is the samily for whom I told you I had so warm an affection; and this the young gentleman whose alliance I recommend for Miss.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Air.
SP.P: Grace, Toby!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fl.
SP.P: I make no doubt, madam, but my niece will think herself happy in an union with so accomplished a person.

SP.SPEAKER: Air.
SP.P: Why, as to that, Toby, Mrs.—what is the gentlewoman's name?

SP.SPEAKER: Flaw.
SP.P: Mrs. Fleece'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Air.
SP.P:
I recollect, madam, going some years ago with one of that name in the stage-coach to York—we were overturned about a mile beyond Newark—the parson of the parish—he
became afterwards a prebend of Worcester, in the room of old Walter Wench'em, who was cast in a suit of crim. con. by Sir Timothy Tally∣hoe, remarkable for the best pack of hounds in the country—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Air.
SP.P: For Heaven's sake, Mr. Aircastle!

SP.SPEAKER: Flaw.
SP.P: Have a care! you have forgot.

SP.SPEAKER: Air.
SP.P: I am dumb.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fl.
SP.P: Pray; madam, has the young gen∣tleman travelled?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Air.
SP.P: Who? Toby?

SP.SPEAKER: Air.
SP.P: Why, madam, I did once intend—but Sir Roger Ramble—who I am told will be strongly opposed next election, for the borough of Barnstaple, by Sir Walter Win'em—who during the whole time of Sir Robert Walpole's admin—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Air.
SP.P: Mr. Aircastle, I beg pardon, but the lady directed the question to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Air.
SP.P: True, my angel; and I am sure nobody can give a better answer than dear Mrs. Aircastle—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Air.
SP.P: You are very polite.

SP.SPEAKER: Air.
SP.P: But I was willing to save you the trou∣ble, my soul.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Air.
SP.P: I shall think it no trouble to satisfy the lady's enquiries.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fl.
SP.P:
Nay, it was a matter of curiosity only:—There is, besides, an elegance, a je ne
scai quoi, in your son's air, that is rarely acquired in this country.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Air.
SP.P: Did not I tell you the prodigious power of grace?

SP.SPEAKER: Air.
SP.P: Yes; but I could never have believed it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Air.
SP.P: Pray, madam, is the young lady at home?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fl.
SP.P: Just lain down for a little: The change of climate has given her a slight indis∣position; but a few days, I dare say, will restore her.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Air.
SP.P: Miss, I presume, has a physician?

SP.SPEAKER: Air.
SP.P: A what? a physician, my lise, for a little sea-sickness? Why, doctor Diet, at Margate, who, by the bye, intends to settle in London—his aunt, major Mortar's widow—who was killed by a bomb at the taking of Goree—Tom Truant, an old scoolfellow of mine, was close by his side—Tom Tru—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Air.
SP.P: Dear Mr. Aircastle, what has all this to do with the young lady's illness?

SP.SPEAKER: Air.
SP.P: I was coming to that, my soul, if you will let me. I don't know how it happens; in general, nobody is better bred than Mrs. Air∣castle; but to-day she won't let me bring out a word.—So, madam, Tom Truant, as I was—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Air.
SP.P: Mr. Aircastle, I must interrupt you!

SP.SPEAKER: Air.
SP.P: You must?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Air.
SP.P: I can't suffer it, upon this lady's account.

SP.SPEAKER: Air.
SP.P: It was for her sake, my soul, I was speak∣ing.—So, madam, Tom Truant—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Air.
SP.P: If you persist, I shall quit the house, I assure you!

SP.SPEAKER: Air.
SP.P: Quit the house?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Air.
SP.P: This very instant!

SP.SPEAKER: Air.
SP.P: Zounds, madam, if you come to that, you may go to the—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Air.
SP.P: Any where to get rid of your absurd—

SP.SPEAKER: Air.
SP.P: For that matter, you can't be more willing than I.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Air.
SP.P: Then, madam, I take my leave.

SP.SPEAKER: Air.
SP.P: When you will: This lady and I can settle matters without you.—So, madam, as I was saying, Tom Tru—

SP.SPEAKER: Flaw.
SP.P: For Heaven's sake, Sir!—Mrs. Air∣castle, calm!—when things are just bringing to bear—

SP.SPEAKER: Air.
SP.P: All I meant was for the service of Miss.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fl.
SP.P: Very obliging, indeed. I should be sorry if any disference should arise on my niece's account; Besides, her illness is so trifling, that the young gentleman may, if he pleases, step into her room to enquire after her health.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Air.
SP.P: Toby will be very happy, I am sure. You see, madam, what the lad is.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fl.
SP.P: A most agreeable youth, I must own; and then his silence is a modest mark of his merit.

SP.SPEAKER: Air.
SP.P: Do you hear that, Mrs. Air—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Air.
SP.P: Yes; and I hope it will make a proper impression on you.—You, doubtless, madam, know the taste of your niece; may we hope that Toby has any chance of succeeding?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fl.
SP.P: She was prodigiously pleased with Mr. Flaw's account of his parents; which, in∣deed, I now find to be true in every respect.

SP.SPEAKER: Air. and Mrs. Air.
SP.P: Oh, madam!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fl.
SP.P: And as to fortune, she is totally careless in that, her own being much more than sufficient.

SP.SPEAKER: Air.
SP.P: How manly that is in a woman!—I re∣member Miss Patty Plumb of Jamaica did the very same—they say her grandfather was trans∣ported for robbing a hen-roost—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Air.
SP.P: But as to his figure, madam; do you apprehend it will strike her? Toby, hold up your head!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fl.
SP.P:
I can see no reason against it: Indeed, the young gentleman has rather a sairer com∣plexion than what she has been commonly used
to; the natives of India, from their climate, have rather a fallower hue.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Air.
SP.P: True, madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fl.
SP.P: But, if necessary, that may be easily altered by art; some saffron, or snuff, just skimmed over his sace—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Air.
SP.P: Quickly!

SP.SPEAKER: Air.
SP.P: I have a box of Scotch in my pocket: It may be done in an instant.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fl.
SP.P: Their hair, too, is most commonly dark; but a little German blacking here on each of the eyebrows—

SP.SPEAKER: Toby.
SP.P: Is a burnt cork will do, I have one in my pocket.

SP.SPEAKER: Air.
SP.P: Mr. Flaw, will you ring for a candle?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fl.
SP.P: There is no necessity now: We have been obliged to shut out the light, as her eyes are rather tender and weak, with looking so long on nothing but water.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Air.
SP.P: True, madam. Well, madam, we will detain you no longer: I am sure it is im∣possible to say how much we are obliged—you may rely upon it, we shall ever be grateful.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fl.
SP.P: I don't in the least doubt it: Mr. Flaw has, I presume, hinted my situation?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Air.
SP.P: Most minurely: Mr. Aircastle has prepared the deposit. You have the needful?

SP.SPEAKER: Air.
SP.P: All but five hundred pounds, which you may have in the evening: I lent it just now to a—the story will make you laugh, I am sure: As I was going out, colonel—who commanded last war—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Air.
SP.P: Is this a time for a story?

SP.SPEAKER: Flaw.
SP.P: Fy, fy! dispatch, Mr. Aircastle!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Air.
SP.P: Here all the bills are.

SP.SPEAKER: Flaw.
SP.P: Nay, hold a little, I beg! This, you know, is a kind of compact; there are condi∣tions to be performed on both sides: Therefore the money should, I think, be lodged in neutral hands, till the material point is complied with.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Air.
SP.P: There is no occasion.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fl.
SP.P: I can have no objection, I am sure: where then shall we place it?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Air.
SP.P: Mr. Flaw is a friend to both par∣ties—

SP.SPEAKER: Air.
SP.P: True; the properest man in the world.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fl.
SP.P: I am not quite so certain of that.

SP.SPEAKER: Air.
SP.P: There, there the bills are, Mr. Flaw.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Air.
SP.P: Now we will leave Toby and the lady together.

SP.SPEAKER: Air.
SP.P: Toby, don't forget to deliver the presents.

SP.SPEAKER: Toby.
SP.P: I have them here in a box.

SP.SPEAKER: Air.
SP.P:
Mind your behaviour, my good lad!—I wish we had time though to doctor his face:
Against their next meeting, I will do it myself; I will manage that matter, I warrant: I learnt the art last autumn of a parcel of strollers—they had been playing, during the Dog-days, with one Foote in this town—a fellow, they say, takes peo∣ple off, and—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Air.
SP.P: Nay, Mr. Aircastle, come along, I beseech you!

SP.SPEAKER: Air.
SP.P: Well, well! you are always in such a damnable hurry!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fl.
SP.P: Mr. Flaw, you are not going, I hope? because I wanted just to speak a few words—

SP.SPEAKER: Flaw.
SP.P: I shall be back in a minute.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fl.
SP.P: This, Sir, this is the door; tread softly.

SP.SPEAKER: Toby.
SP.P: Had not I better pull off my shoes?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fl.
SP.P: No occasion for that.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fl.
SP.P: This way! your hand!—Letty, my dear, the young gentleman I mentioned to you this morning, begs just to enquire after your health. There; I will leave you together: She is in the bed at the upper end of the room. I make no doubt, Sir, but you will behave with proper decorum.

SP.SPEAKER: Toby.
SP.P: If you are afraid, you need not go out of the room.—The place is as dark as a dungeon! Upper end of the room! and how the deuce should I know which that is? in the night, I can tell you, I should be a good deal frightened to be so much in the dark, but it is well enough in the day, when one is about to make love; because why, one is not so bashful and shy; one can see to speak one's mind with more boldness and cou∣rage, than in the light.—Me—Miss! I thought she had spoke; may be not. If I could but get hold of the curtains—the best way will be to creep close by the wall, then I shall be sure to—Miss! Miss!

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Who be dat dere?

SP.SPEAKER: Toby.
SP.P: I.—Dat dere? one may find out by her tongue she is a foreigner: I am pretty right now, I believe. What, Miss, are you sick?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Iss.

SP.SPEAKER: Toby.
SP.P: But you are better, I hope?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Iss.

SP.SPEAKER: Toby.
SP.P: I am glad on't: Then I suppose, Miss, if you please, I may begin to make love?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Iss.

SP.SPEAKER: Toby.
SP.P: Iss? gad, I think it is ready made to my hands.—Did the gentlewoman, Mrs. Madam your aunt, say any thing about and concerning of me?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Iss.

SP.SPEAKER: Toby.
SP.P: Is it a secret?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Iss.

SP.SPEAKER: Toby.
SP.P: Oh, then it would not be manners to ax: Well, Miss, I hope you ben't averse to the match?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Iss.

SP.SPEAKER: Toby.
SP.P: Adzooks, then we are all off in an instant! What, Miss, I suppose you ben't willing to have me?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Iss.

SP.SPEAKER: Toby.
SP.P: Oh, then we are on again, as before: Then I may produce, I believe. I have brought you, Miss, some curiosities, by way of present∣ation, here in my pocket: Will you please to accept—

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Iss.

SP.SPEAKER: Toby.
SP.P: Here, then, I offer them up to the shrine of thy beauty. May I crave leave to kiss your lily-white hand?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Iss.

SP.SPEAKER: Toby.
SP.P: On my knees let me thank you, fairest creature!—Her skin is vast soft. They be won∣derful pretty things I have brought you; a'n't you mighty curious to see them?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs.
SP.P: Iss.

SP.SPEAKER: Toby.
SP.P: May I draw up the curtain a bit, only just to give you glimpse?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Iss.

SP.SPEAKER: Toby.
SP.P: So I will.—I should be glad to have a peep at her too; she is a mighty agreeable body; does not talk much, indeed; but is vast sensible, whatever she says. This, I believe, is the string. I wonder if she is as handsome as Betsy Blossom: Gad, if she is, Miss Blossom must look out for somebody else, I can tell her. That's high enough, I believe.—That there thing in the leather-case is a watch; if you touch the nob that juts out, it strikes all the world like a clock; mother has one, but then him is as big as a warm∣ing-pan. Perhaps, Miss, you mayn't find the trick out: I'll shew you.—Hey! what is this? Lord have mercy on me! she is turned all of a sudden as black as a crow! sure as can be, a judgment for forsaking poor Betsy.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Massa, won't you come here?

SP.SPEAKER: Toby.
SP.P: Not I.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: I come to you, den.

SP.SPEAKER: Toby.
SP.P: The devil you will! you must run pretty fast then.—Keep off me! holloa! house! stop the black thing that is hard at my—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fl.
SP.P: The rude puppy had like to have run over me: What is the meaning—Ha, the curtain drawn up? nay then—Maranne, who opened the window?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Little Massa, to shew me de tick-tick—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fl.
SP.P: Fool, did not I tell you—But it was my own fault, to trust such an ideot! Go, get out of my sight!

SP.SPEAKER: Flaw.
SP.P: What the deuce is the matter? Toby is scampered down the street as if he had a legion of—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fl.
SP.P: Matter? why he has discovered the wench.

SP.SPEAKER: Flaw.
SP.P: 'Sdeath! I told you the folly of trust∣ing these—we shall all be blown up in an instant: I saw the mother stop her chariot at the sight of the whelp; so I suppose we shall have her back in a—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fl.
SP.P: Ay? then something must be sud∣denly done.

SP.SPEAKER: Flaw.
SP.P: Done! but what?—I'll run after the boy, and hear his account of the matter.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fl.
SP.P: Stay! had not you better, Mr. Flaw, just leave with me Mr. Aircastle's deposit?

SP.SPEAKER: Flaw.
SP.P: Pho! time enough; is this a season to settle accounts?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fl.
SP.P: So! I suppose he will march off with the money at last: I would have done as much, if I could but have touched it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Air.
SP.P:
Dear madam, I am in the utmost
confusion! I am afraid that wild boy has misbe∣haved himself in some manner or other.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fl.
SP.P: A little mistake, madam; but I protest my niece is so terrified, that she is unable to give me any account—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Air.
SP.P: Some rude prank of his, I dare say; I never could get his father—

SP.SPEAKER: Gorget.
SP.P: The house is in such confusion, that I can't get any body to give me an answer.—Mrs. Aircastle!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Air.
SP.P: Bless me, Colonel Gorget! who thought of meeting you here?

SP.SPEAKER: Gorget.
SP.P: An odd affair; but this lady, I sup∣pose, Mrs. Fleece'em, will be so kind to explain it. A pretty young lad, an ensign of mine, has, I am afraid, been tricked out of a large sum of money by one Flaw, a fellow of very bad fame.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Air.
SP.P: How! Flaw?

SP.SPEAKER: Gorget.
SP.P: Under pretence of gaining promotion by this lady's assistance.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fl.
SP.P: Mine, Sir? I promise you this is the first mention I ever heard of the matter.

SP.SPEAKER: Gorget.
SP.P: Just, Madam, as I suspected: But pray, Mrs. Aircastle, have you long had the honour of this lady's acquaintance?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Air.
SP.P: Acquaintance? Lord, colonel, I am terrified out of my wits. Your ear for a moment.

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.P: A note, madam, which you are desired directly to read.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fl.
SP.P: Flaw's hand. [Reads]. “The game is up—we are blown—make off as fast as you can.” As matters stand, the best advice I can take.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Air.
SP.P: Madam, you are not going to leave us?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fl.
SP.P: Only just to enquire how my niece does after her fright: I shall be back immediately.

SP.SPEAKER: Gorget.
SP.P: How! is it possible? a capital sum? Good Heavens, madam, and how could you trust it without consulting some friend?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Air.
SP.P: Why, we both thought Mr. Flaw—

SP.SPEAKER: Gorget.
SP.P: Flaw? an infamous—

SP.SPEAKER: Air.
SP.P:
Why, what the deuce has been the matter amongst you? They tell me Toby has been at home frightened out of his wits; and then run out directly with the waiter and some wench or other:
I have sent your Roger in search of the whelp.—Ah, colonel, are you there?

SP.SPEAKER: Gorget.
SP.P: Came the minute before you.

SP.SPEAKER: Air.
SP.P: Well, colonel, hy, how? What, I sup∣pose, by being here so soon, your affair has mis∣carried.

SP.SPEAKER: Gorget.
SP.P: You are mistaken indeed, my good friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Air.
SP.P: What affair?

SP.SPEAKER: Air.
SP.P: I forgot to tell it you, child: Of a fine lass in this town, that sets up her person for sale—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Air.
SP.P: How!

SP.SPEAKER: Air.
SP.P: And had the modesty to fix the price to the colonel at five hundred guineas.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Air.
SP.P: Abominable! Can there be such creatures?

SP.SPEAKER: Air.
SP.P: Ask the colonel; that is all: An infamous harpy!

SP.SPEAKER: Gorget.
SP.P: Dear Mr. Aircastle, you are here in an error.

SP.SPEAKER: Air.
SP.P: Error? why, did not you tell me of a line she sent you?

SP.SPEAKER: Gorget.
SP.P: Very true.

SP.SPEAKER: Air.
SP.P: And did not I advance the cash?

SP.SPEAKER: Gorget.
SP.P: Do I pretend to deny it?

SP.SPEAKER: Air.
SP.P: Well then?

SP.SPEAKER: Gorget.
SP.P: Your patience a moment, my dear friend! I gave her the money, it is true—

SP.SPEAKER: Air.
SP.P: There, Mrs. Aircastle! did not I tell you—

SP.SPEAKER: Gorget.
SP.P: But then, like a woman of honour—

SP.SPEAKER: Air.
SP.P: Well?

SP.SPEAKER: Gorget.
SP.P: She told me that she did it but to try the strength of my passion—

SP.SPEAKER: Air.
SP.P: Pho, pho!

SP.SPEAKER: Gorget.
SP.P: And so immediately returned it again.

SP.SPEAKER: Air.
SP.P: Pshaw! a bam, Mrs. Aircastle; don't believe it, my dear!

SP.SPEAKER: Gorget.
SP.P: To put the matter out of dispute, I returned to your lodging directly; when, not finding you, I delivered the cash to your lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Air.
SP.P: Indeed?

SP.SPEAKER: Gorget.
SP.P: In the very individual bag that you gave me; and before Master Toby, your son.

SP.SPEAKER: Air.
SP.P: Ay? and have you got the money, my dear?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Air.
SP.P: Yes, yes; I received it.—Was ever woman so duped! but this town is full of Cozeners.

SP.SPEAKER: Gorget.
SP.P: I am afraid, Mr. Aircastle, that it was pretty lucky for you I happened to have the cash in my hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Air.
SP.P: Lucky? I don't understand—

SP.SPEAKER: Gorget.
SP.P: Otherwise, it might have slown away with the rest.

SP.SPEAKER: Air.
SP.P: Flown away?

SP.SPEAKER: Gorget.
SP.P: By what Mrs. Aircastle has told me, I shrewdly suspect you are got into the hands of some villainous sharpers.

SP.SPEAKER: Air.
SP.P: How!

SP.SPEAKER: Gorget.
SP.P: Mr. Flaw, and his coadjutrix.—Within! who's there?—But we shall soon get the business explained.

SP.SPEAKER: Gorget.
SP.P: Do you live with the person who inhabits this house?

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: But a very short time.

SP.SPEAKER: Gorget.
SP.P: We wish to see her directly.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: She is gone out.

SP.SPEAKER: Gorget.
SP.P: I thought so: And her niece too, I suppose?

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Her niece, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Gorget.
SP.P: Ay.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: I know no niece she has.

SP.SPEAKER: Air. and Mrs. Air.
SP.P: How!

SP.SPEAKER: Gorget.
SP.P: Just as I suspected: Now, Sir, do you begin to find what a situation you are in?

SP.SPEAKER: Air.
SP.P: Then I am totally ruined! I told you, Mrs. Aircastle, what would come of your—I remember Martin Moneytrap, of the Minories, was once in the very same way—he was taken-in by a Portuguese Jew—

SP.SPEAKER: Gorget.
SP.P:
A truce to recrimination, I beg! we
have more material business in hand: Let this woman be directly pursued; and endeavour to recover at least a part of—

SP.SPEAKER: O'Flan.
SP.P: Pray step in a bit, if you plase, and refund freely the bill; or, upon my soul, I'll make you do me the favour by force!

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: Mrs. Fleece'em?

SP.SPEAKER: O'Flan.
SP.P: Yes, yes; it is, sure enough; she overtook me, as I met her hard by.

SP.SPEAKER: Gorget.
SP.P: We are obliged to you then for the lady's return?

SP.SPEAKER: O'Flan.
SP.P: You may say that: I stopped her just in the nick, as she was sily walking off in a coach. Arrah, put off your hood, my dear honey; don't be shame-aced amongst your friends and acqntance.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. .
SP.P: Stand off, you rude brute!

SP.SPEAKER: O'Flan.
SP.P: Better words, if you plase! You wanted to send me to be feathered abroad; so, in return, I shall beg lave, madam, to pluck you at home.

SP.SPEAKER: Gorget.
SP.P: No violence to the lady I beg, Sir! she now finds she is detected, and, I dare say, will do every body all the justice she can. And, first, madam, as to the capital sum which you had the address to obtain from this—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fl.
SP.P: What concern have I in the busi∣ness? the gentleman himself gave it into the possession of Flaw.

SP.SPEAKER: Gorget.
SP.P: Mr. Aircastle!

SP.SPEAKER: Air.
SP.P: That's true, I confess.

SP.SPEAKER: Gorget.
SP.P: But, since that, has not the property suffered a transfer?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fl.
SP.P: Not to me: But if you doubt it, you may search the house when you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Gorget.
SP.P: Then it has got into worse hands, I'm afraid.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Sim.
SP.P: I see by their confusion my infor∣mation was right.—Not to interrupt you, madam, I should take it as a particular favour if you would immediately return the little note I left in your hands—for I have not a moment to spare.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fl.
SP.P: Note, madam? what note? I re∣collect, indeed, a hymn that you—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Sim.
SP.P: Well, madam, that hymn, if you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fl.
SP.P: I gave it directly to Flaw, to get a friend of his to set it to musick.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Sim.
SP.P: Musick? Ladies and gentlemen, a bank-note, I protest!

SP.SPEAKER: Air.
SP.P: What! set a bank-note to musick? I never heard of such a thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Gorget.
SP.P: And pray, madam, what could induce you to trust that woman with a bank-note?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fl.
SP.P: That she will not so readily own; a little earnest of a much larger bribe, to procure her husband a living.

SP.SPEAKER: Gorget.
SP.P: How, madam! I hope your husband was not apprised of this application?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Sim.
SP.P: The Doctor was totally ignorant; knew nothing about it.

SP.SPEAKER: Gorget.
SP.P: I am very happy to hear it: I should be sorry to find that a gentleman, whose pecu∣liar duty it is to sustain the purity of his pro∣fession, should himself be the very person to soil it; or that an office of so sacred a nature, should be solicited by such unsanctified means.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Sim.
SP.P: I believe my Doctor, Sir, will be hardly suspected: But I have not time to say more for the prefent; I shall be stay'd for, and have not a moment to spare.

SP.SPEAKER: Gorget.
SP.P: Let her go! that plunder, however, is fair.

SP.SPEAKER: Air.
SP.P:
Well, well! but, colonel, notwith∣standing all that you say, I have heard there was a bet once made between the patron of a living and one Parson Plurality—Plurality had
been a Presbyterian—his father keeps a pastry-cook's shop in Spring-gardens—just where Cox's Museum—by the bye, they tell me, Cox will get devilish rich by his lottery.

SP.SPEAKER: Gorget.
SP.P: But if we don't use some dispatch, I am afraid you will get devilish poor.
SP.STAGE: Enter Prig, in a waistcoat and cap.

SP.SPEAKER: Prig.
SP.P: Where is this damn'd infernal—she is burrow'd here, but I'll make her—

SP.SPEAKER: Air.
SP.P: Who the deuce can this be?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fl.
SP.P: Some madman escaped from his keepers, I reckon.

SP.SPEAKER: Prig.
SP.P: Yes, yes, I am escaped! but not mad: and if there is law to be had, I'll make you to know—keepers!—if I had not luckily met with some friends at the trnpike, I should have been kept pretty close, I believe. I recollected your footman that stood at the door, and guess'd you were not far off.

SP.SPEAKER: Air.
SP.P: What is this? a madman? I went to see one once in Bedlam—he—

SP.SPEAKER: Air.
SP.P: Oh, here is Roger. Well, did you find where Toby is?

SP.SPEAKER: Roger.
SP.P: Yes, yes, I found un out; and in sweet company too.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Air.
SP.P: Company?

SP.SPEAKER: Roger.
SP.P: A clergyman, Betsy Blossom, and our waiter at home,

SP.SPEAKER: Air.
SP.P: Zounds! I hope the boy is not married.

SP.SPEAKER: Roger.
SP.P: No; but they would have been, if I had not come just in the nick to fetch un away.

SP.SPEAKER: Air.
SP.P: Where is he?

SP.SPEAKER: Roger.
SP.P: In a shop at the corner. I wanted un to step over; but he would not, because why, he says as how the house is haunted.

SP.SPEAKER: Air.
SP.P: And why not? There was the manor-house in the parish of Paddington—Mrs. Air∣castle, you may remember it formerly belonged to the Jessops; but, by the marriage of the heiress with one of the Haslewoods—

SP.SPEAKER: Gorget.
SP.P: Come, come, it is a lucky prevention; and, to give you a little consolation, I believe I shall be able to recover your money from Flaw.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Air. and Air.
SP.P: How, colonel?

SP.SPEAKER: Gorget.
SP.P: I took the liberty, by way of preven∣tion, to get him secured for the money received of my ensign.

SP.SPEAKER: Air.
SP.P: Indeed?

SP.SPEAKER: Gorget.
SP.P: And, as this affair is rather of a crimi∣nal nature, he will think himself happy to escape by restoring the plunder.

SP.SPEAKER: Air.
SP.P: My kind colonel!

SP.SPEAKER: Gorget.
SP.P:
I hope, madam, this will make you
amends for your disappointment in the five hun∣dred pounds.

SP.SPEAKER: O'Flan.
SP.P: But what the divil is all this to my bill?

SP.SPEAKER: Gorget.
SP.P: Did this woman receive it?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fl.
SP.P: Flaw had it; but it wants some days of being due.

SP.SPEAKER: Gorget.
SP.P: Then we shall be able to stop the pay∣ment, at least; it is safe, never fear.

SP.SPEAKER: O'Flan.
SP.P: That's lucky, however: And, by all I can hear, my best way, Mr. Colonel, will be to make an emigration back to Ireland again.

SP.SPEAKER: Gorget.
SP.P: By all means; and, by this time, many more of your countrymen would, I believe, be glad to follow your steps.

SP.SPEAKER: O'Flan.
SP.P: Like enough.

SP.SPEAKER: Air.
SP.P: And if, Mrs. Aircastle, we were to re∣turn back again—

SP.SPEAKER: Gorget.
SP.P: It would be the wisest thing you could do.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Air.
SP.P: What, to vegetate, like a parcel of plants?

SP.SPEAKER: Gorget.
SP.P: Ay, madam; for there are trees that won't bear transplanting; they thrive best in their natural soil.

SP.SPEAKER: Air.
SP.P: That's true, I can answer. Last summer, I transplanted some elm-trees—

SP.SPEAKER: Gorget.
SP.P: Lord! Mr. Aircastle, how can you—

SP.SPEAKER: Air.
SP.P: Zounds! I must n't speak—Sir, let me tell you the story of the elm.

SP.SPEAKER: Gorget.
SP.P: You, mdam, till you have made all the satisaction you can, must be contented to suf∣fer a little confinement; after which, unless your country should have some other cll upon you, you may dispose of yourself as you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fl.
SP.P: I am detected, distrssed, and must therefore submit! But, gentlemen, if all who have offended like us, were like us produced to the public, much higher names would adorn the Old-Bailey Chronicle than those of poor Fleece'em and Flaw!

DIV1.P: In the Press, and will be published in a few Days, The COMEDIES of The Maid of Bath, AND The Devil Upon Two Sticks; Both written by the same Author, And published by the same Editor.
